coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Towson Seminar
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Introduces students to college-level work and academic expectations.
learningOutcomes: Prepare and present a compelling substantive interpretation, argument, and/or analysis of a problem or issue in a research paper.
Gather and use academic resources effectively and according to the standards and rules of academic integrity.
Understand and evaluate the nature and possible causes and implications of events, behavior, problems, and issues from an informed and balanced perspective.
Connect concepts and empirical evidence in logically coherent, valid, and compelling ways.
Understand and appreciate social and cultural differences and engage constructively with others from different backgrounds.
Participate responsibly and effectively in group efforts to address and solve problems.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: English Composition
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Focuses on writing and thinking in the branches of knowledge and developing rhetorical strategies for expository writing.
learningOutcomes: Write academic essays that effectively and appropriately respond to specific rhetorical situations.
Improve literacy skills, including the ability to read and analyze a variety of texts.
Organize an essay around a sound central idea supported by relevant material.
Organize supporting material with a discernible and logical plan.
Present ideas in complex and effective sentences relatively free from mechanical errors.
Support and share ideas and opinions with confidence.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Mathematics
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Requires skills at the level of college algebra or above, emphasizing both theoretical foundations and problem-solving applications.
learningOutcomes: Construct and evaluate logical arguments.
Apply and adapt a variety of appropriate strategies to solve mathematical problems.
Recognize and apply mathematics in contexts outside of mathematics.
Organize and consolidate mathematical thinking through written and oral communication.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Creativity and Creative Development
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Emphasizes symbolic, affective, and imaginative thinking in creative activity and understanding the creative process through participation.
learningOutcomes: Apply in practice a range of expression within a specific art while exhibiting rigorous standards of technique.
Demonstrate content knowledge through an analysis and synthesis of representative examples, ideas, and skills.
Articulate the ways in which theory and practice meet in the creation of the specific art form.
Show how history, aesthetics, form and composition, techniques, and pedagogy contribute to the process of creative development.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Arts and Humanities
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Explores aesthetics, values, and cultural heritage through subjects like literature, art, music, and philosophy.
learningOutcomes: Discuss the context and structures of cultural traditions in terms of literature, art, music, culture, or society.
Describe important movements and processes that have affected the cultural heritage of a particular group.
Use methodologies associated with the study of cultural traditions in the arts and humanities.
Engage in a critical assessment of how the studentâ€™s own experience has been affected by particular cultural traditions in the arts and humanities.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Social and Behavioral Sciences
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Examines the psychology of individuals and the ways in which individuals, groups, or segments of society behave, function, and influence one another.
learningOutcomes: Articulate relevant basic assumptions, concepts, theoretical constructs, and factual information of the social and behavioral sciences.
Demonstrate an understanding of relevant social and behavioral science methodologies.
Apply appropriate problem-solving skills in discipline-specific contexts.
Apply disciplinary knowledge from the social and behavioral sciences to contemporary ethical or social issues.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Biological and Physical Sciences (with Lab)
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Investigates living systems and the physical universe, emphasizing scientific inquiry, historical development, and application of scientific concepts.
learningOutcomes: Utilize scientific vocabulary and examples to describe major ideas appropriate to a specific scientific discipline.
Use quantitative reasoning to analyze and/or support scientific information.
Identify, describe, critique, respond to, and construct the various components of the scientific process.
Explain scientific issues of current importance to society within scientific, technological, historical, societal, and ethical contexts.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Biological and Physical Sciences (Lab & Non-Lab)
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Focuses on scientific inquiry and understanding, with an emphasis on non-lab courses or additional lab sciences from a different discipline.
learningOutcomes: Understand and evaluate the processes of scientific inquiry in non-lab settings.
Demonstrate comprehension of major scientific ideas and methodologies.
Analyze current scientific challenges from a variety of perspectives.
Connect theoretical knowledge with practical applications in scientific studies.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Advanced Writing Seminar
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Focuses on discipline-specific writing practices and techniques of formatting, reporting, and documentation.
learningOutcomes: Recognize and employ models and practices of written communication specific to a particular discipline or profession.
Recognize and employ techniques of formatting and documentation appropriate to a particular discipline or profession.
Integrate material effectively from outside sources into their own prose.
Analyze and evaluate complex discipline-based claims and current research questions.
Compose clear, effective prose, including through the practice of revision.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Metropolitan Perspectives
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Examines and explores the metropolis in its past and present complexities, describing characteristics or dynamics of metropolises.
learningOutcomes: Analyze the complexities of metropolitan areas in historical or contemporary contexts.
Evaluate the impact of cultural, economic, and political systems on metropolitan development.
Understand and articulate issues related to urbanization and metropolitan growth.
Engage in interdisciplinary exploration of urban spaces and their dynamics.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: United States as a Nation
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Explores the institutions, history, culture, or traditions of the United States, addressing broader national experiences.
learningOutcomes: Analyze and describe the evolution of key U.S. institutions, values, and traditions.
Evaluate the dynamics of change and continuity in the history and culture of the U.S.
Apply interdisciplinary methods to examine the United States as a nation.
Discuss the diversity and complexity of American experiences across different eras and communities.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Global Perspectives
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Examines how the global environment is changing and being shaped by major social, cultural, religious, economic, political, and technological forces.
learningOutcomes: Analyze the impact of social, cultural, religious, economic, and political forces on global relationships.
Understand how global interdependence shapes and is shaped by individual and collective actions.
Apply interdisciplinary approaches to investigate global patterns and relationships.
Evaluate major global challenges and propose informed responses.

coreCurriculumRequirements.name: Diversity and Difference
coreCurriculumRequirements.subject: CORE
coreCurriculumRequirements.description: Explores relationships of distinctiveness and interdependence, conflict and cooperation, between and among people with varying cultures, beliefs, identities, and capabilities.
learningOutcomes: Critically assess the nature and implications of cultural differences.
Demonstrate an understanding of how distinctiveness and interdependence shape relationships.
Engage in constructive dialogue across diverse perspectives.
Evaluate the dynamics of conflict and cooperation among diverse groups.
